definition: A TypeScript class that controls a portion of the screen
detailedExplanation: Components are the fundamental building blocks of Angular applications. A component controls a patch of screen called a view and is defined by a TypeScript class with the @Component decorator. Components define application logic that enables the user experience inside a template.
codeContext: Used with @Component decorator to create reusable UI elements

definition: A design pattern where objects receive dependencies from external sources
detailedExplanation: Dependency Injection (DI) is a design pattern and mechanism for creating and delivering some parts of an application to other parts that need them. Angular has its own DI framework which is used extensively throughout the framework to provide services to components and other services.
codeContext: Used with @Injectable decorator and inject() function

definition: A class that provides specific functionality across components
detailedExplanation: Services are a great way to share information among classes that don't know each other. Services are typically decorated with @Injectable and can be injected into components or other services. They help keep components lean and focused on supporting the user experience.
codeContext: Created with @Injectable() decorator for dependency injection

definition: A contract that defines the structure of an object or class
detailedExplanation: TypeScript interfaces define the shape of objects, providing type safety and documentation. They specify what properties and methods an object should have, enabling compile-time type checking and better IDE support with autocomplete and error detection.
codeContext: Used to define object structures and method signatures

definition: A class that adds behavior to elements in Angular templates
detailedExplanation: Directives are classes that add additional behavior to elements in your Angular applications. Angular has three kinds of directives: Components (directives with templates), Attribute directives (change appearance or behavior), and Structural directives (change DOM layout).
codeContext: Used with @Directive decorator to extend HTML functionality

definition: A stream of data that can be observed over time
detailedExplanation: Observables are a key part of reactive programming in Angular. They represent a stream of data that can emit multiple values over time. Observables are lazy, meaning they don't execute until something subscribes to them. They provide operators for transforming, filtering, and combining data streams.
codeContext: Used for handling asynchronous data streams and HTTP requests

definition: A reactive primitive for managing state changes in Angular
detailedExplanation: Signals are Angular's reactive primitive that notifies interested consumers when its value changes. They provide a simple and performant way to manage state and trigger updates only when necessary. Signals can be computed, writable, or derived from other signals.
codeContext: Used with signal(), computed(), and effect() functions

definition: A function that transforms data for display in templates
detailedExplanation: Pipes are a useful way to transform data in Angular templates. They take data as input and transform it to a desired output for display. Angular comes with built-in pipes like date, currency, and async, and you can create custom pipes for specific transformation needs.
codeContext: Used in templates with | operator or @Pipe decorator for custom pipes

definition: Angular's navigation system for single-page applications
detailedExplanation: The Angular Router enables navigation from one view to the next as users perform application tasks. It interprets browser URL changes as instructions to navigate to a client-generated view and can pass optional parameters to the supporting view component.
codeContext: Configured with Routes array and RouterModule

definition: Angular's model-driven approach to handling form inputs
detailedExplanation: Reactive forms provide a model-driven approach to handling form inputs whose values change over time. They use explicit, immutable data structures to manage form state, making forms more scalable, reusable, and testable.
codeContext: Built with FormControl, FormGroup, and FormBuilder classes
